Award.AwardTitle: Technique development of a MEMS-based heating stage for high-pressure transmission electron microscopy in the earth sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Minerals at elevated pressure (P) and temperature (T) provide essential information about the interior of Earth and other planets. Knowledge of their properties and phase transitions under extreme conditions provides unique insights into seismic discontinuities, mantle plumes, mantle turnover, and other dynamic effects that occur inside planets. Transmission electron microscopes (TEMs) are the only instruments that provide the resolution needed to study high-P minerals at the atomic level.

Controlled sample heating within a TEM is critical for the high-P measurements. However, it is highly challenging to obtain the required mechanical stability, minimal thermal drift, and rapid settle times, all within the small sample area of a TEM. Heating stages have recently been greatly superseded in thermal and mechanical stability, and thereby accuracy, by a totally new design for TEMs that is based on MEMS (micro-electro-mechanical systems) technology on tiny solid-state chips. This technology also permits analytical electron microscopy (AEM), including energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), at elevated temperatures. Such analyses at high Ts were heretofore not possible in a TEM. MEMS heating systems have not yet been used in the earth sciences. The goal of this project is to develop this method of heating within a TEM and its utilization for studying minerals at mantle conditions. We anticipate that the results of these developments will provide a significant improvement and expansion of high-P measurements. It will be possible, for the first time, to observe the structure, behavior, and properties of earth materials at atomic resolution in situ at the PT conditions in Earth?s lower crust and mantle. The results will provide fundamental new knowledge about the nature of geologically and geophysically important minerals at extreme conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal and key achievement of the project is the development of a new method for heating mineral samples at precisely controlled temperatures within a transmission electron microscope and then combining that heating with simultaneous application of high pressures. The purpose is to utilize this procedure to study minerals at conditions simulating deep within Earth and also to stimulate new ideas regarding reactions and processes at elevated temperatures and pressures. The advantage of making such measurements within an electron microscope is that one can thereby avoid the changes that are incurred during quenching from extreme to ambient laboratory conditions prior to detailed sample studies, as happens using other techniques. In this way, dynamic physical and chemical processes in minerals as well as their structures and crystallographic defects can be observed in real time at the atomic level under the conditions existing in Earth’s deep crust and mantle.

 

Generating high pressures is accomplished by placing samples inside tiny cages (nano-cages) whose walls consist of sheets of carbon atoms (graphene). Individual carbon atoms are then displaced from the walls of these nano-cages by energetic electron bombardment within an electron microscope, causing the nano-cages to shrink, thereby squeezing their contents and thus applying high pressures on the encapsulated sample. Temperature control within the small confines of an electron microscope is difficult, but became possible through use of a totally new design for the heating stage that is based on micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) technology on tiny solid-state ceramic chips. The new stage has the benefit of allowing heating to over 1,200 ºC, with accuracy of ±5 ºC, within microseconds as well as increasing or decreasing the sample temperature equally rapidly and under tight thermal control. These exceptional capabilities, plus ultrahigh thermal stability and ultralow sample drift that the MEMS heating stage uniquely provides, make it possible to capture dynamic changes in minerals in real time. Additionally, it allows chemical analyses using energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) at up to 800 ºC, which was not previously possible in an electron microscope.

 

Use of the MEMS stage has allowed us to observe the structure, behavior, properties, and dynamic processes of earth materials at atomic resolution at the high pressures and temperatures that occur in Earth’s lower crust and mantle. The results provide a significant improvement and expansion of high-pressure measurements, and the ideas they provoked are providing fundamental new knowledge about the nature of geologically and geophysically important minerals at extreme conditions. The project is also stimulating new ideas for the hydrogen isotopic composition and origin of terrestrial water and a MEMS-based experimental project to test those ideas. By adding another procedure with the unique capability of high-resolution imaging, the small high-pressure armamentarium for studying materials in situ at high pressure and temperature has been significantly expanded.
